{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the information provided, the radiograph of the upper lateral incisor showed a periapical lesion after 2 years following root canal treatment (RCT). Curretage was done and histopathology showed the presence of an apical cyst. However, the lesion continued to enlarge even after surgery. Given this information, the most likely reason for the continued enlargement of the lesion is that there is an unobturated accessory canal. This means that during the initial root canal treatment, an additional canal in the tooth was not properly cleaned, shaped, and filled, leading to persistent infection and the growth of the periapical cyst. Leaking from the main canal, apex not resected, and actinomycosis infection are less likely explanations based on the provided information.", "answer_choice": "B"}
